Description: Unique reference identification number for biomass equation source. Links to Reference table.
Unique equation identification number given arbitrarely. Links to Site_Species table.
Equation to calculate biomass (includes coeficients given in original publication)
Algebraic form of the biomass equation (as function of DBH, HT, WD or others)
Tree component characterized by the equation
Parameters included in biomass model (HT: tree height (m); DBH: diameter breast heigh (1.3 m); DBA: diameter at base; WD: wood density)
Species, genus, family, or plant group for which the allomery was developed (sometimes used as proxy species to calculate AGB when a specific-species equation is not available)
Specific taxonomic level for which the biomass equation was developed (species, genus, family or plant group)
Geographic location from which trees were sampled to develop the original equation
Latitude in decimal degrees
Longitude in decimal degrees
Elevacion in meters.
Generalize clasification on type of ecosystem
Brief drescription of forest, summarized from original publication
Minimun DBH (cm) sampled to develop the equation
Maximun DBH (cm) sampled to develop the equation
Number of trees sampled to develop the equation
Year(s) of measurement if  in publication
DBH unit used in original publication
Field_codes: cm: centimeters; inch: inches; mm: milimeters

Description: Conversion factor applied to convert DBH unit used in original publication into an equivalent expressed in cm. Multiply by number given in table.
Mass or length unit used in original publication
Field_codes: g= grams; kg= kilograms; lbs= pounds; metric_ton= metric ton; Mg= megagrams; m= meters

Description: Conversion factor applied to convert unit used in original publication (mass or length) into an equivalent expressed in kg or m. Multiply by number given in table.

Method used to develop the allometry. Traditionally, this is done by harvesting whole trees, drying, and weighing ("harvest").  However, we anticipate that many future allometries will be developed using ground-based LiDAR ("lidar").
Regression model used in original publication
Original R-squared value given in publication
Comparable models if reported in publication (given equation form)
Whether the regression fit is done with biomass as the response variable (i.e log(biomass) base 10)
Indicates if a correction factor (CF) or a relative standard error (RSE) was included in model
Correction factor for the specific equation, pulled from original publication, if included
Other details on statistical methods
Unique identification  or clues given in original publications
Indicates whether or not the original source data is available
Notes or error message to indicate any pitfall that could spoil the AGB estimate based on equation selected
